ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In this course, we read a broad array of articles and chapters of famous novels related to environmental issues and philosophy. It was a good introduction to writing an essay at college, and especially helpful when it came to our largest assignment: the research paper.
There were a lot of topics covered in this course and each was taught in a very engaging manner. The overarching skill for this course was critical reading as it was used in every lesson.
Learned to write clearly and efficiently while developing a cohesive argument. Also learned some art history and environmental philosophy.
I developed the ability to analyze art academically, have informed conversations about climate change, and write more persuasively in a variety of formats.
Learned how to become a more competent and analytical writer.
I developed my critical reading skills and discussion skills.

I learned about various types of writing, including personal and research papers. I also learned about different perspectives that humans have about the environment, what is considered to even be the environment, and our future in it.
How to write essays in American

By taking this course, I broadened my knowledge on 18th century landscape painting, the state of the environment, and nature writing (with writers like Cronon and Thoreau). I think that one of the most valuable lessons that this course brought was the fact that it opened my eyes to the true danger of global warming through literature, and helped me overcome the fear that I previously had on reading about global warming.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The greatest strength of this course is that the assigned readings are designed to be interesting, which makes class conversations more exciting. We also had the opportunity to visit an art gallery -- a field trip that all the students seemed to enjoy. I think it would have been nice if the grading of the papers was a bit more clear, because sometimes grades had a lot of explanation attached while other times there seemed to be less feedback.

The small amount of students in the course is a huge benefit to the lessons, as the opinions of each student can be heard. The lessons operated more like conversations and the students had a lot of influence over directions which the lessons took.

Overall a great course. The readings were very engaging and fascinating. I think it would have sometimes been helpful if we had more shorter writing assignments throughout the course that asked us to give our thoughts about a reading or asked us to talk about how we thought multiple readings related to each other. Our class discussions were not always the best, in part I think because some didn't do the readings or skimmed them too quickly.

The biggest strength was the instructor (Jakub is amazing), but the inconsistency across other English 114 classes is a major weakness (some are much easier than others and many are much less engaging than others).
Strength was that the course was very engaging, and it had a very interesting take on the landscape and environment-something I had never learned before.
One of the strengths of this class was its flexibility and how Jakub structured it around what interested us. Also, letting the students guide discussions was useful.

The course was very strong in its directions. I never felt lost in this class. My teacher was very good at providing feedback and keeping me on track. This course could be improved by discussing the technical aspects of writing more, such as how to vary sentence and paragraph structure.
Reading topics varied throughout the weeks but some were irrelevant to homework essays

I really enjoyed the conversational flow of the classes, which made them engaging and interesting, sometimes even funny. The readings I always found to be interesting and discussing them was always incredibly constructive. However, I think that the course lacked a bit of cohesion, since I found it hard to find a connection between 18th century landscape painting and global warming. Making some of the readings more connected, as well as the themes taught in class, could be a good way to improve it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student because it teaches you how to write a essay about something that is interesting, all in a way that is not stressful and very straightforward. I enjoyed seminars because the topic allowed us to share personal experiences and opinions.

I would definitely recommend this course to other students because of how interactive the course is and how familiar students become with the material. There was always something new to discuss and every student was constantly engaged.
yes. A good english seminar topic!
Yes. I absolutely loved this course, and I would recommend it to anyone at Yale, regardless of major or interests. It is a phenomenal class.
Yes, it is a very great introduction to writing at Yale, and it gives you a better perspective of what is expected from you as a college student writer.
Yes I would because I enjoyed the material while learning some useful skills about reading academic papers.
Yes. I learned so much about the environment and really enjoyed our class discussions. The different writers that we studied were very interesting and provided great writing material.
Yes for students wanting to learn about essay writing

Yes! This is a great way to improve your writing and at the same time learn about 18th century landscape painting and the effects of global warming. It's a course that makes you aware of your surroundings in so many ways.
